title: Transurban chairman Lindsay Maxsted seeks three more years
text:
The company's stock price, which has benefited from investors looking for high-yielding stocks as interest rates drop, is up 32 per cent over the past 12 months compared with a 6.8 per cent rise in the S &P/ASX 200.

Both the ASA as well as CGI Glass Lewis and ISS have recommended investors vote in favour of all resolutions at the AGM, including Transurban's remuneration report and the grant of performance awards to chief executive Scott Charlton.

ISS has welcomed better disclosure of financial performance hurdles for executives in Transurban's 2019 annual report, but says its non-financial targets "remain opaque" and that some of Mr Charlton's individual performance measures appear to be a bonus for what should be his regular "day job."

In addition, it has reiterated concerns over the high level of Mr Charlton's remuneration compared with other Transurban executives.

Mr Charlton earned $7.2 million in financial 2019, an average of four times more than other Transurban executives.

The next highest paid executive was Jennifer Aument, the president of Transurban's North American business, and Transurban chief financial office Adam Watson, both of whom were paid $2 million in the same period.

Mr Maxsted told The Australian Financial Review after the company's 2018 AGM, where some 11 per cent of votes were cast against its remuneration report, that the pay gap had emerged because Transurban had a young executive group, but argued other executives' remuneration would increase as they took on more responsibility.

Advertisement

CGI has also criticised the pay disparity, pointing out that keeping an equitable distribution of pay supports succession planing by preventing "demoralisation" of the executive team and helping retain potential CEO replacements.

"Since oversized CEO pay is usually the sign of an all-powerful CEO, internal pay equity can also serve as a check on a CEO's authority," CGI said.

"A high level of executive pay inequity, as in this case, may indicate long-term problems with the company's remuneration practices and more broadly, its board-level management and oversight."

ISS has also questioned Transurban's "less than rigorous" free cash flow hurdles in its long term incentive plans, pointing out that the cash flow vesting scale for its 2019 grant was in the range of 5.5 per cent - 7.5 per cent, down from a year earlier where the vesting range was 8 per cent - 10 per cent.

"The rigour of the lower free cash flow targets for a highly-modelled toll road infrastructure business like Transurban may be of concern to shareholders, who may question whether such adjustments are made in light of modelling results, which in turn, result in a greater likelihood for long term incentive vesting," ISS said.

Transurban's long term incentive awards granted between financial 2013 and fiscal 2015 fully vested and its FY 2016 and financial year 2017 awards will vest above 80 per cent.

The ASA said it would raise concerns at the AGM on whether the free cash flow targets were "too soft." Mr Charlton will receive $3.38 million worth of equity rights if he meets all performance measures under his 2019 long-term incentive plan over the next three years. The ASA wants the performance period to be extended to four years.
description: Transurban's chairman wants to stick around as the tollroad group's share price outperforms the S&P/ASX 200.
